title: Ultrafast broadband BT rival claims 'landmark' Edinburgh deal
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 08:46 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 44 mins Ultrafast broadband BT rival claims 'landmark' Edinburgh deal By Christopher Williams | Telegraph – 9 hours ago -12.00 
CityFibre to connect 300 council buildings as it seeks to become 'credible alternative' 
CityFibre, the telecoms upstart aiming to challenge the dominance of BT’s Openreach division, has claimed a “landmark” deal to in Edinburgh provide ultrafast broadband to nearly 300 council sites. 
The company said the deal was worth as much as £16m and at least £5.6m and comes months after it began rolling out a fibre-optic ‘core’ network across the Scottish capital. 
CityFibre shares spiked 12.5pc on the announcement, which represents the company’s largest contract win to date. 
It made its debut on AIM last year after being founded on fibre-optic infrastructure bought from liquidators following the collapse of H2O Networks. The stricken company was so-called because of its plans to piggyback ultrafast broadband networks on existing sewer networks in mid-size towns such as Bournemouth. 
Edinburgh Council previously relied on BT’s part-copper-wire infrastructure to connect many of its services and buildings. CityFibre’s new network, being built in collaboration with local telecoms retailer Commsworld, is fibre-optic throughout, providing the council and around 7,000 businesses with internet access more than 10 times faster than BT’s superfast broadband service. 
Greg Mesch, CityFibre’s chief executive, said: “A future-proof wholesale network of this size provides a credible alternative to that provided by BT Openreach and points to the crucial role of competition at an infrastructure level for the technological and economic development of the UK’s towns and cities." 
There are no firm plans yet to connect the network to homes, but CityFibre is working with Sky (LSE: BSY.L - news ) and TalkTalk on an ultrafast domestic broadband rollout in York that is designed to establish the economics of such an investment. 
BT is coming under increasing pressure from alternative infrastructure providers, although they still represent a small slice of the market. 
Virgin Media’s £3bn expansion plan, Project Lightning , has now added more than 250,000 properties to the cable network, and is on track to hit four million by 2020.
